CHRIS HAMILTON: At Odd Bot,
we're an animation studio that

produces Soup to Nuts,
2D, CG, kids and family.

Projects that we've worked on,
Muppet Babies for Disney Junior.

MS. NANNY: Is everything
all right out here?
ALL: Yes, Ms. Nanny.

CHRIS HAMILTON: Action
Packed for Netflix,

and currently working on
Playdate with Winnie the Pooh
for Disney Junior.

ALL (SINGING): What
are we going to play?

CHRIS HAMILTON: So we did
two seasons, traditionally,

a traditional CG show
of Winnie the Pooh,

and then we decided
that the third season we
were going to do all in Unreal.
POOH: Let's go play.

CHRIS HAMILTON: For
the first two seasons,

we never really got
involved in the CG
portion of the production.

We would just get footage
back and then give

notes, lots of notes, lots
draw overs, send it back.

And now with Unreal
Engine, we were

able to scale up
just a little bit,

build up our team just
slightly, and we can take
on much more of the production.

We have a lot more creative
control and the ability

to-- yeah, to play
a little bit more.

ELISE FACHON: It's
really about the fact

that multiple departments
can work simultaneously.

We would have our 3D board
artists laying out the 3D board,

and we would start
lighting right away.

So animation is happening
while lighting is happening.

We're doing renders
the whole time

where we're checking the final
look of it in storyboard.

We've been iterating
all the way through,

and we just wind up
with a final product

that much more meets
our expectations
in a much faster timeline.
[LAUGHING]

SAMMY RIVKIN: Lighting the
season was a totally new thing
for the entire crew.

We've never had lighters
in-house before.

We had a biweekly
live lighting session.

So we actually got to sit,
tweak things in real time,
and adjust as we went.

ELISE FACHON: You can sit
and look in the viewport

and go, oh, could we
tweak this a little bit?

Can we adjust this rim light and
see it happening in real time?

And that was just this
moment of "holy cow,
what can't we do with this?"
Which is really exciting.

TIGGER (SINGING): Owl
softly hooting in the sky.
[HOOTING]

ELISE FACHON: We definitely
had a distinct challenge

with Playdate with
Winnie the Pooh,

where we have all of
these fuzzy characters,

and they have to feel
super soft and charming.

And all of the characters
have a different look to them.

We really set out
to replicate with

Unreal Engine all of those
different kinds of fur looks

and fur simulations
to really give us

that character range that we
had in season one and two.

FRANK LIMA: Most of the
characters all had grooms,

and the grooms consist
of hundreds of thousands
of follicles.

And not only the
characters, but we

decided to use a groom
system on the grass.

So all of the sets
that have grass
are just one giant groom system.

And at the end of
the day, we were

getting into the billions
of hair follicles rendered
at any given time.

That actually allowed
us an additional benefit

for simulation, and we
could now bend and move

the grass to whatever
we'd like to do.

And we can see that
in the viewport live.
We can scrub back and forth.
Let's make it more stiff.
Let's make it more loose.

And then we get that feedback
and iteration real quick.

ELISE FACHON: It's
instant gratification.

[LAUGHS] I feel like
that's what we're

all kind of hoping for is
we want to see it the way
we want it instantly.

And in this process,
it's just done.
PUPPET 1: Wow!
PUPPET 2: Nice to meet you.
PUPPET 3: Nice to meet you.

ELISE FACHON: One of
the things that we

run into with the projects
that we're working on

is, more than ever,
there's a demand

for bespoke content for
Instagram, YouTube, verticals,

for reels, all these
kinds of things.

In a traditional pipeline,
that has to go all the way back

to rendering and
different layouts,

and you've got to do a
whole different camera pass.

It's too costly,
too time consuming.

And with Unreal Engine, you can
set up your camera much more

easily, back it up,
and just get everything

that you want in your shot for
your vertical much more quickly,

and render the whole
episode, and be

able to generate that
kind of companion

content for social
media channels really
quickly and easily.

SAMMY RIVKIN: As
a producer, it's

always been a huge goal of
mine to have a team that

works incredibly well
together as one unit,

and also gets to enjoy the
fun of making cartoons,

because we do make
cartoons for a living.

Reels brought out this
beautiful collaboration

that isn't necessarily
needed in a more assembly
line traditional pipeline.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
PIGLET: Yay!

POOH: They're one of
my favorite crafts.

ELISE FACHON: So
this whole season

was kind of a leap of faith
for Odd Bot and Disney.

Disney was so enthusiastic about
what they were seeing early on.

We'd sent through
a storyboard that

would have lighting, and grass
in it and character textures.

Some of the storyboards
looked like final renders.

That really helped sort of just
set everyone's expectations
on what was possible.

CHRIS HAMILTON:
Children's animation

is challenging because
there's this expectation

that every show needs to look
different and be different,

which is one of the most
exciting parts about children's
animation.

There's so many different styles
and so many different looks,

and with Unreal
Engine, it's enabled
us to play more, be creative.
And that's really exciting.
